headline: Ties between California and Venezuela go back more than a century with Chevron
summary: Chevron, the oil giant founded and until recently headquartered in California, is the only foreign petroleum company still operating in Venezuela and its largest foreign investor.

headline: Trump administration sets meetings with oil firms on Venezuela: source
summary:
STORY: Donald Trump's administration is planning to meet with executives from U.S. oil companies later this week.

That's according to a Reuters source, who says the meetings are to discuss boosting Venezuelan oil production after U.S. forces ousted country leader Nicolas Maduro.

The administration is eyeing getting U.S. oil companies back into the South American nation, after its government took control of U.S.-led energy operations there nearly two decades ago. 

The White House did not comment on the planned meetings.

But said it believed U.S. industry was ready to move into Venezuela.

The three biggest U.S. oil companies - Exxon Mobil, ConocoPhillips and Chevron - did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

According to four industry executives, the three firms have not yet had any conversations with the administration about Maduro's ouster.

That contradicts Trump's statements over the weekend.

The president said he had already held meetings with all the U.S. oil companies, both before and after Maduro was seized.

Trump also said that he expects the firms to spend billions of dollars to boost Venezuela's oil production.

But industry analysts say those plans will face challenges.

They cite lack of infrastructure, and deep uncertainty over the country’s political future and legal framework, as well as doubts over long-term U.S. policy.

headline: Trump Tells Oil Giants to “Get Ready” for a Post-Maduro Venezuela
summary: President Donald Trump is pressing U.S. oil majors to prepare for large-scale investment in Venezuela following the capture of Nicolás Maduro, though industry enthusiasm remains uncertain given the scale, cost, and risks involved.

content.title: Trump Tells Oil Giants to “Get Ready” for a Post-Maduro Venezuela
content.summary: President Donald Trump is pressing U.S. oil majors to prepare for large-scale investment in Venezuela following the capture of Nicolás Maduro, though industry enthusiasm remains uncertain given the scale, cost, and risks involved.

headline: Why Venezuela’s Oil May Be Far More Trouble Than It Is Worth for Chevron and Other Companies
summary: President Donald Trump wants U.S. companies to rebuild Venezuela’s oil industry, but Venezuelan oil can’t simply be turned back on.  Chevron Exxon Mobil  and  ConocoPhillips  have long histories in the country, though only Chevron operates there now.  In theory, those companies could turn Venezuela into a gusher, ramping up the country’s production of 1 million barrels a day now.

content.title: Why Venezuela’s Oil May Be Far More Trouble Than It Is Worth for Chevron and Other Companies

Chevron Exxon Mobil  and  ConocoPhillips  have long histories in the country, though only Chevron operates there now.  In theory, those companies could turn Venezuela into a gusher, ramping up the country’s production of 1 million barrels a day now.

headline: Trump Tells NBC He May Reimburse Venezuela Oil Investments
summary: Trump said the project to have US oil industry companies expand their operations in the country could be “up and running” in less than 18 months, in an interview Monday with NBC News — a timeframe starkly at odds with estimates from energy industry experts, while oil companies have been largely silent about their willingness to reinvest in Venezuela.  “I think we can do it in less time than that, but it’ll be a lot of money,” Trump told NBC.

content.title: Trump Tells NBC He May Reimburse Venezuela Oil Investments

headline: Why Analysts See The Exxon Mobil (XOM) Story Shifting On Cash Returns And Sector Caution
summary: The fair value estimate for Exxon Mobil has inched from US$131.56 to US$131.32, a tiny adjustment that reflects only modest tweaks to the model rather than any major shift in the story. This slight move lines up with research that balances confidence in cash generation and capital returns with some caution around sector sentiment and future margin trends. Keep reading to see how you can stay on top of these incremental narrative changes as they emerge over time. Stay updated as the Fair Value...

headline: Wall Street mixed in light trading before the opening bell while oil prices resume their climb
summary: Trading on Wall Street was mixed in light trading early Tuesday while gains for oil prices moderated following the U.S. military operation in Venezuela over the weekend the led to the capture of its president, Nicolas Maduro.  Nasdaq futures rose 0.2%.  Following a bigger jump on Monday, oil prices at first retreated overnight before rebounding early Tuesday.

headline: How Much Oil Does Venezuela Really Have? For Chevron, the Truth Matters.
summary: Investors are raising doubts about how much oil Venezuela really has and whether it could be profitably extracted.  Venezuela’s oil has long been tantalizing—and problematic.  The term “proved reserves” represents oil deemed recoverable under certain technical and economic assumptions, but not necessarily oil that can be produced quickly or cheaply.

content.title: How Much Oil Does Venezuela Really Have? For Chevron, the Truth Matters.
content.summary: Investors are raising doubts about how much oil Venezuela really has and whether it could be profitably extracted.  Venezuela’s oil has long been tantalizing—and problematic.  The term “proved reserves” represents oil deemed recoverable under certain technical and economic assumptions, but not necessarily oil that can be produced quickly or cheaply.

headline: Venezuela's oil supply isn't a 'buy' signal for energy stocks
summary:
STORY: After robust gains on Monday, oil stocks dipped on Tuesday, with giants Exxon Mobil and Chevron down more than 2% and 4%, respectively.

"The world right now [has] a surplus of oil," Chopra explained. "The oil that's coming out of Venezuela is heavier, so it requires higher complexity and more development in terms of refiners."

But the potential for more oil output from Venezuela in the years to come could lower oil prices, which Chopra said could help bring down "global inflation over time."

content.title: Venezuela's oil supply isn't a 'buy' signal for energy stocks

"The world right now [has] a surplus of oil," Chopra explained. "The oil that's coming out of Venezuela is heavier, so it requires higher complexity and more development in terms of refiners."

But the potential for more oil output from Venezuela in the years to come could lower oil prices, which Chopra said could help bring down "global inflation over time."

headline: Chip stocks jump on AI optimism; Dow ends at record high
summary:
STORY: Wall Street ended higher on Tuesday, with the Dow gaining about 1% to hit another record high, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq both climbing more than six-tenths of a percent.

Investors brushed aside fears of broader geopolitical fallout after U.S. forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro over the weekend.

Rohit Chopra, portfolio manager at Lazard Asset Management, said investor focus is already turning to what happens next.

"And now markets are starting to digest some of those second-order developments. What is the oil production outlook look like? What type of investment will come in? What is the type of regime that we're likely to see? But I do think the markets are taking more of a [glass] half full approach to this weekend's developments."

Still, oil stocks dipped after robust gains in the prior session, with giants Exxon Mobil and Chevron losing about 3.5% and 4.5%, respectively.

Renewed AI optimism powered the indexes, with several chip stocks rallying.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang, speaking at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, gave details about upcoming AI processors that include a new layer of storage technology.

SanDisk surged more than 27%, Western Digital jumped 17%, Seagate Technology gained 14% and Micron Technology rose 10%, with all four stocks hitting record highs.

But Huang's comments also raised concerns about demand for data center cooling systems. Shares of Johnson Controls slid more than 6%, while Trane Technologies dropped 2.5%.

Among other movers, shares of Moderna jumped almost 11% after BofA Global Research raised its price target on the drugmaker.

content.title: Chip stocks jump on AI optimism; Dow ends at record high

Among other movers, shares of Moderna jumped almost 11% after BofA Global Research raised its price target on the drugmaker.

headline: Trump says US to get 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil from Venezuela at market price
summary: President Donald Trump said Tuesday that Venezuela would be providing 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil to the U.S., and he pledged to use proceeds from the sale of this oil “to benefit the people” of both countries.  The White House is organizing a meeting Friday with U.S. oil company executives to discuss Venezuela, which the Trump administration has been pressuring to open its vast-but-struggling oil industry more widely to American investment and know-how.

content.title: Trump says US to get 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil from Venezuela at market price
content.summary: President Donald Trump said Tuesday that Venezuela would be providing 30 million to 50 million barrels of oil to the U.S., and he pledged to use proceeds from the sale of this oil “to benefit the people” of both countries.  The White House is organizing a meeting Friday with U.S. oil company executives to discuss Venezuela, which the Trump administration has been pressuring to open its vast-but-struggling oil industry more widely to American investment and know-how.
